competencies.name: Driver conducts daily checks listed in Defect Book in a well-lit area away from main traffic routes
Driver checks First Aid box including eye wash to ensure it is complete
Driver checks the external cleanliness of the vehicle including lights, number plates , indicators and windows
Driver checks that the cab is clean and free from unauthorised items
Any defects identified and reported to appropriate personnel
competencies.supportingText: 1. What is the procedure for reporting defects to supervisor?

competencies.name: Driver wears high-visibility clothing provided by the company together with any other relevant personal protective equipment
Driver has required documentation for their load
Driver ensures that only authorised passengers ride in the vehicle and that seat belts are worn at required times
competencies.supportingText: 1. Why are unauthorised passengers not allowed to ride in the vehicle?

competencies.name: Driver ensures that employees do not ride on the back or any other part of the vehicle
competencies.supportingText: 1. Why is it important that employees do not ride on the back or any other part of the vehicle?

competencies.name: Driver ensures the safety self, the public and other road users when stopping, starting and positioning the vehicle
Driver operates vehicle safely: •following public highway traffic convention•with due consideration to others
Driver ensures that no loading takes place while the vehicle is in motion
Driver check that the vehicle is loaded safely with no over-loading or overhanging items
competencies.supportingText:
1. Why is it necessary to remove over-hanging items?
  2. Why is it necessary to check the vehicle is not over-loaded?

competencies.name: Reversing operations are conducted safely following company procedure (or as detailed in WAP9)
Driver always wears company issued high-visibility clothing whenever out of the cab together with any other relevant personal protective equipment issued to them
Driver is aware of and complies with all site safety rules when on customer’s premises or tipping sites and ensures that crew members comply
competencies.supportingText:
1. What are the major safety rules that must be complied with on customer’s premises?
  2. What are the major safety rules that must be complied with on tipping sites?
  3. How do you ensure that the crew know the safety rules and how do you check they comply with them?

competencies.name: Driver ensures skip content is within scope of permit and contract for collection (so far as reasonable) and seeks removal of material where it is not
Driver ensures only authorised persons operate the lifting equipment
Driver ensures the proper operational condition of chains and ensures they are properly and securely fitted before lifting or dropping skips
Driver ensures use of all necessary stabilisers or jacks when lifting or dropping skips
Driver examines skip to ensure that there are no protrusions near the tipping bar that could snag on the tipping hooks giving a false engagement condition
competencies.supportingText:
1. How do you check for protrusions near the tipping bar?
  2. What is likely to happen if the protrusions are not removed?

competencies.name: Snagging hazards are identified and supervisor is notified
competencies.supportingText: 1. What is the procedure for notifying your supervisor of snagging hazards?

competencies.name: Driver ensures the skip is not overfilled and takes appropriate action to reduce overfilled skip
competencies.supportingText:
1. What are the major signs that a skip has been overfilled?
  2. What is the appropriate action to take reduce an overfilled skip?

competencies.name: Driver makes a visual check to ensure that the hooks have properly engaged on the catch bar
Driver ensures that the use of stabilisers or jacks does not compromise the effectiveness of brakes by raising the braked wheels
Driver visually assesses the drop area, the access to it, and any likely damage that may be caused to paving, grassed areas or so-called hard standings
Where doubt exists the skip is not dropped and advice is sought from supervisor
competencies.supportingText:
1. What are the major reasons for deciding not to drop a skip?
  2. What is the procedure for notifying your supervisor that you do not want to drop a skip?

competencies.name: Before both reversing and operating the lifting arms the driver checks that the arms come no closer than three metres to any overhead obstructions such as power cables
Driver ensures that members of the public, especially children, are kept well away when loading or unloading skips
Driver ensures that skips are not left where they may cause any unauthorised blockage or obstruction of the highway and must be clearly lit when left on public roads
competencies.supportingText:
1. What are the major restrictions on the placement of a skip?
  2. What checks do you carry out when leaving a skip on a public road?

competencies.name: Driver decides whether or not it is safe to pick up a filled skip
Driver contacts supervisor in the event of overfilled or over-spilling skips
competencies.supportingText: 1. What is the procedure for contacting your supervisor in the case of an overfilled or over-spilling skip?

competencies.name: Driver sheets skips from ground level
competencies.supportingText: 1. Why must skips only be sheeted at ground level?

competencies.name: Driver does not climb onto the back of the vehicle
Driver applies tension chains in transit with a bungee rope to avoid chains becoming detached from the skip lugs
competencies.supportingText:
1. How do you identify when tension chains are required for transit of skips?
  2. How do you apply a bungee rope to the tension chains of a skip?

competencies.name: Driver securely stows all sheets, chains, ropes and any other items  in the under slung box provided during transit
Driver defects the vehicle if a box has not been provided and notifies supervisor
competencies.supportingText: 1. What is the procedure for notifying your supervisor when a box is not present?

competencies.name: Driver clears any debris from the truck bed by using an extended broom or similar without climbing on the truck bed
Driver contacts supervisor if in doubt about loading and removal procedures
competencies.supportingText: 1. What are the major concerns that would make you seek your supervisor’s advice about loading or removing a skip?

competencies.name: Driver carries only one loaded skip on the bed of a vehicle
competencies.supportingText:
1. How can you tell if a vehicle is safe to carry more than one skip?
  2. How do you go about ensuring the safety of a load with multiple containers piggy backed on each other?

competencies.name: Driver piggy backs empty containers only when the load can be safely secured
Driver complies with all site safety rules when on customer’s premises or tipping sites
Driver follows tip rules in force when discharging loads at tipping sites and also ensures compliance of the crew
Driver takes great care when reversing to a tip edge to prevent the vehicle from going over the edge
Driver does not stand or allow others to stand or work under a suspended skip
Visual checks are undertaken for each tipping operation ensuring that the hooks have properly engaged on the catch bar
Drivers does not allow anyone to climb into the skip
